question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

3. I gained insight into the birth of archaeology as a field, as well as ongoing debates and movements within the discipline.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class, I learned about different ways to think historically about objects, sites, and people in the long history of Athens and Attica. I was introduced to a wealth of archaeological techniques and terminology, as well as rich information about the stories, cultural practices, and art of ancient Athens.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the history of Athens and Greece from the Neolithic all the way up to the modern day (in varying detail based on the time period). I learned about some methods of archaeology, like periodization and use of typology. I also learned to look at and consider different types of archaeological evidence, including textual, material, and topographical evidence.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned about Roman history and why the Romans were so enraptured in spectacle. 
I learned that there was a lot of influence of Greek culture 
I learned that the modern world could be comparable to the Romans

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about why the Ancient Romans had the spectacles they had such as the gladiator fights, beast hunts, and chariot races. Even though gladiator fights are probably the most well-known widely, especially as brutally violent, almost sadistic spectacles, they had a greater purpose in Roman society at the time. I also learned that there was a time when the Romans did not build permanent spectacle buildings but rather built temporary ones but with good reason. I have developed a better understanding of this ancient civilization in particular and this has also allowed me to be more open-minded when it comes to thinking out other cultures or civilizations doing things that may seem odd to us but make a lot of sense when you see it from their perspective.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the chronology of Rome and its founding, some of the major figures in Rome's history, and how to view history from the perspective of an oppressed person.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) Analyzing secondary sources--some primary sources
2) Engaging with perspectives of marginalized groups in history

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned cultural institutions of early Rome through the Empire, including Roman virtues, class structure, and traditions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about Ancient Roman culture, how to read and learn from ancient and modern sources, and to critically think about history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read ancient texts and engage in active dialogue with them as well as comparing and synthesizing information from multiple sources. I also learned how to engage with non literary texts, especially things like graffiti, and how to infer things from people who did not commonly have a say in the way history was preserved or society was perceived. The writing assignments were also very flexible and I had to exercise a bit of creativity in there, which was nice compared to the heavier writing of my other history classes.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Analyzing primary sources, "history from below" (understanding Roman history from less documented perspectives), overview of Roman history

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read against the biases of extant sources, how to interweave multiple types of evidence to form a more complete story, and how to engage with the broad themes of Roman culture.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned lots about Roman social values, themes in epic poetry, and satirical practices. Learning about Roman life from a variety of sources both written and archeological was so much fun.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course was organized. I knew exactly when I needed to submit homework and what was expected of me for each assignment. The midterm projects were challenging but not overwhelming in difficulty. The clemensia was a good way to make up for missed assignments.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: While I found the reading annotations rather arduous, the questions posed were thought-provoking and always made me engage with the material. The lack of tests and quizzes does not seem to have hampered my retention of any information--a testimate to the extremely deliberate way in which subjects are covered and reintroduced in lecture.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the discussions in class always reinforced the themes we explored in our readings before each class and helped inspire me when it came to midterm assignments where I had to reference stuff from throughout the semester. I would definitely keep the storytelling and poetic assignments as it definitely was a major creative outlet for me in particular.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I want to cover more history. The only emperor we learned about was Augustus. It would have been interesting to learn about Constantine and Christianity in Rome. I think I would find it more intellectually stimulating to memorize dates and times than talk about oppression one more time. I wanted a more holistic view of Roman history instead of focusing on some female poetry for a full day.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I found the use of material culture sources very beneficial, as well as the sections of the class in which we read Livy and Virgil. I really enjoyed getting into the classic classical texts. I would have preferred less emphasis on "underclass" perspectives.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class activities and homework were really conducive to staying engaged with the material and always really fun.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The open-ended nature of the three midterm writing assignments allows students to engage with sources and themes they found the most impactful. The large number of readings and participation assignments also engenders constant cogitation.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I loved our creative writing assignments! I really showed me just how much I'd learned throughout the semester and motivated me to get as much as I could from reading to reading.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would not recommend taking this class. I like Classical studies, and this was not interesting to me at all. The course is not that hard to get an A, but I derived little value in terms of education. Unless you are a super woke liberal, you will not enjoy this class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If I were to do it again I would probably not had taken this course. Professor Ginsberg is knowledgeable, but I did not like her focus on less traditional perspectives in Rome, as I had hoped to get more of a classical history background on Rome through Constantine. The course takes a very progressive approach to Roman history, and I did not find it agreeable.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's my favorite course I've taken at Duke, and I'm not remotely a classics major. I learned so much, and had a great time in the class. Professor Ginsberg is the best at what she does and I only wish she taught more undergrad courses.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this class! It is not an unbearable amount of work and the professor is amazing. Ginsberg is seriously a rockstar in the field and she makes you think outside the box than what is usual in a classics class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: One of my favorite classes at Duke! Would recommend to anyone of any major

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Understanding how different cultures have so much more in common, but at the same time they have small differences is something really stimulating. To see how these ancient cultures understood/defined life and their interpretations of what was going on around them was something really interesting to learn about.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

I feel like I learned so much and it was never super stressful but it didn't feel like a throwaway class either. I had so much fun with this course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course it really fun if you are at all interested in mythology, but it is also a great way to contextualize ancient cultures by examining their stories. There are a lot of readings, but giving yourself time to interact with them not only makes your more prepared for class discussion but also helps broaden your own understanding. Also participating in discussion allows you to share your thoughts and glean insight from other students' understanding.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1. I've learnt, at least the foundations of seven different religions and traditions. They're all very interesting and offer valuable insight on how to approach different aspects of the good life.2. I've learnt to pick and choose more effectively. The seven different traditions and religions offer important lessons on different aspects of life. I agree with some, and disagree with others. For example, I appreciate the pragmatism of Stoicism (I think of myself as stoic to an extent), but some things to me are not indifferents, they're simply bad. I prefer Confucianism's focus on ritual in dealing with loss.3. I've learnt to appreciate writing more. We did a lot of writing in this class, particularly with the jounral entries and the many notes and questions we did in class. It's brought back a lesson I learnt from my old writing teaching: "writing is thinking". I've done a lot of thinking through writing in this class.

response_text: The lectures are not particularly stimulating. Professor Antepuli, who taught us about Islam, was the only one I always wanted to hear more from, because of how engaging of a lecturer he was. I would suggest a total revamp of the lectures: more guest lecturers and case studies or real-world examples related to the religious concepts discussed (prompting us to apply the knowledge to practical situations). As well as the use of multimedia elements such as videos, documentaries, and interactive simulations to supplement traditional lectures and field trips to religious sites or events, allowing students to experience and observe religious practices firsthand.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The class truly has the power to transform ideas. Hearing from such a diverse group of people, all experts in their fields, allowed me develop my own perspectives over life's biggest questions. The course is a truly one of one experience for sophomores, in this critical time of our lives. The teachings of various traditions allowed me to see the world in a whole different light.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to understand different points of view and relate with each other to find common ground in thought. In light of several issues concurrently happening around the world, this class was a breath of fresh air that allowed civil conversation organized by the amazing professors. The retreat also was placed at such a perfect time when I was studying for midterms, helping me escape the Duke bubble. Life at Duke isn't in any way representative of how real life is meant to be viewed or taken. Life is meant to be good. And this class reminded me of how important human interaction and conversation is.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
1) Weekly readings with the questions—really prompted us to actually delve into the readings.
2) Dialogue Groups & DG performances—great way to meet people!
3) THE RETREAT! Such a great embodiment of TI's values, & really helped me relax as a sophomore & meet other people & experience the importance of staying present.
4) Check system for questions & journal entries—removes pressure of thinking in a "correct" way.
5) Dialogue between traditions—having the professors representing the traditions have actual conversations together at the front of the lecture hall.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

I have heard such amazing things about this class and felt a little disappointed with how it actually went. The retreat was absolutely amazing, and I believe the TI program has the potential to keep that energy going the entire class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Duke students often refer to an easy class as a good class. If you want a relatively easy class take this class. If you want a somewhat intellectually stimulating class, I recommend taking a different course. Though the teachers were interesting, the lack of student engagement will impede your own experience. There is a required overnight retreat and a dialogue section weekly which aren't noted on the course description. This course requires you to submit 2 questions a week on canvas, 10 reflective journal entries, 1 acting performance, and 1 final paper. Overall it is a very manageable class. You get what you put into this course, so know that before enrolling.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
1) Weekly readings with the questions—really prompted us to actually delve into the readings.
2) Dialogue Groups & DG performances—great way to meet people!
3) THE RETREAT! Such a great embodiment of TI's values, & really helped me relax as a sophomore & meet other people & experience the importance of staying present.
4) Check system for questions & journal entries—removes pressure of thinking in a "correct" way.
5) Dialogue between traditions—having the professors representing the traditions have actual conversations together at the front of the lecture hall.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think the lack of communication and expectations between students and the professors has made the class a little less stimulating. The interest I and others would gain from lectures is often overshadowed by the confusion regarding deadlines and grading expectations. I know it is hard to coordinate a class with so many students and teachers, but sometimes assignment due dates feel rushed. I have heard such amazing things about this class and felt a little disappointed with how it actually went. The retreat was absolutely amazing, and I believe the TI program has the potential to keep that energy going the entire class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course was structured so that a team of scholars and medical professionals would come into class and give lectures on different areas. I gained unique perspectives from each professional who specializes in their field and gives us a sneak peek of their expertise through each lecture in the class. Indeed, I felt each lecture was a glimpse into the medical field through a different lens. For example, in one lesson we would learn about the social drivers of health and the different broader forces at play impacting the patient’s health, and in another lecture, we talked about the cultural differences in truth-telling in oncology and medicine. Though we learned a wide range of topics, the content all tied back to the core of medicine: the intricate balance between medical knowledge and treatment, caring for patients as a person, and the ethical responsibilities that guide medical practice.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Classes were generally lecture-focused, but we were given time to discuss and encouraged to analyze and think about different sources and evidence. I think this structure worked relatively well, and although participation in discussions was rarely very equally distributed, I personally found these activities to be engaging.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the articles we read before classes provided a good amount of background for what we'd be learning throughout the week, as well as the museum day, and library workshop helping to learn about both how to find resources to utilize in papers, and seeing the reality of the excavation process and getting a hands-on look at archeology and excavations of Athens.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr Judson is very understanding and willing to help us learn and participate in the way that works best for us. I like the lecture combined with some in class discussion and having a lot of room to give ideas in class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the selection of reading materials is really good and I appreciate the effort to pair the material with course content.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The readings and class discussions were very intellectually stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: As an engineering student this class allowed me to work a different part of my brain than my usual classes and I really enjoyed getting to do work that was entirely new to me.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Thinking about how archaeology isn't objective, it can be changed based on who's manipulating it.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: As I said above, the fact that we had take-home tests rather than regular assessments made me want to learn the material instead of just trying to memorize it. I also liked how much of a discussion class was.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think the large span of time that we examined painted a larger picture of how Athens has changed over time, which I found very interesting.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: We were pushed to apply the ideas from objects and history in class to new objects outside of class on our own exams and in our paper. This allowed me to take concepts but connect them through new ideas.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The assignment format was very effective in my opinion, as it relieved the stress of memorizing facts or dates and instead allowed students to have some level of freedom in what they discussed and how they went about presenting their thoughts. The exams and the paper were both great ways for me to demonstrate what I had learned in the class as well as further my understanding of topics that interested me specifically.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This course was an exciting survey of Athenian art, architecture, and culture across time, with specific attention paid to the realities of those who might have lived, worked, and made their lives in Athens. I deeply appreciated discussions towards the end of class about archaeological practice, and what histories were privileged over others. Both Dr. Judson and Daniel approached their instruction with deep enthusiasm, knowledge, and love for sharing the stories, objects, and sites of Athens.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was a new experience for me, and helped me to apply writing skills, and learn new skills to make interesting, and informative papers

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The interactive nature of the course was great, and the exam format is also helpful in demonstrating what we actually learnt and absorbed

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: There are lot of deep dive into a specific site and that gives me different perspective of an ancient civilization.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You leave the course having a great understanding of both the history and the archaeology done at Athens over the years.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Interesting course topic and material, is a fair amount of work though if you are taking for a liberal arts requirement

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! It's a super interesting class and you'll learn a lot, especially if you already have some background knowledge on Athens or are particularly interested in it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take it, especially if you want a taste of archaeology without having a ton of background knowledge.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It’s a wonderful course that feels interdisciplinary. It makes me want to see all of these objects in person and a more observational person.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be ready to learn tons of archaeolgical information you did not know before and change the way you imagine Athens.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's a fun course and an interesting course if you are interested in Ancient Greece or Athens like I am! I enjoyed just learning the content. I would encourage a future student to prepare well for their term paper and pick something that really interests them.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a very interesting class, and if you are really interested in archeology, allows you to get a good zoom in on a specific region to get an idea of the archeology process on a smaller scale

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is very chill and interesting content.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: A lot of archaeology and evidence finding. Not much about analysis and art history

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Knowledge of art markets, value systems, and the shady side of art and archaeology. I learned to think more critically in instances of nuance where an argument for one side or another is difficult.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Historical questioning, ethical questioning, research

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think about loot as an all-encompassing reality (cultural, historical, and archeological settings as well as aspects of law, colonialism, oppression, war, and money). I also learned how to interpret the provenance and provenience of objects to think critically and deeply about whether it is loot. I also learned how to read complex articles, books, and journals that go into the details of an object's history and present circumstances as well as find provenance of an object who does not have much known provenance.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- moral considerations surrounding the ownership of cultural heritage
- evaluation of contested institutions such as museums, archives, and libraries
- (il)legal appropriation of sacred objects

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I knew a bit about looting and provenance as I worked at the nasher reorganizing their provenance files however I didn’t know the legal side of things and this class really introduced me to that.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a significant amount of knowledge regarding how to approach provenance research, balance the complexities of repatriation cases, and navigate the challenging duality of legality and ethics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about how art and artifacts have been used as symbols of power and have been stolen throughout history. I also learned about the legal side of culteral protection which I did not know much about.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to look at the possession of cultural artifacts critically, how to examine and research the provenance of objects and artifacts, and how the repatriation of cultural artifacts works.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Loved the open dialogue and that the profs willingly shared their opinions!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Readings correlated to class discussion, detailed feedback given on assignments

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved the variety of readings and in-depth case studies we did. I particularly liked the field trip as we got to get a hands-on experience with what we had been learning and then got to research an object connected to the place we visited. I would continue to have a variety of topics in the lectures, activities, and field trips.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
- visiting lectures were excellent --> felt like a diversity of perspectives was crucial to the info
- motifs of individual looted objects that tracked along the themes we studied

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Having 3 different professors with 3 different areas of expertise was really helpful. We got such a developed view of the issues that way.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors worked incredibly hard to facilitate our learning by routinely interjecting lectures to ask the students for active feedback. As such, we were constantly encouraged to participate and reflect on the readings that we did before classes. The occasional in-person outside speaker series were an aspect of the class that I believe should be kept for future years since it was such a delight to have such groundbreaking professionals as Patty Gerstenblith and Morag Kersel speak to our class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the form of doing background readings before lecture was useful; the research assignments also fit the themes of the course well.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course was very interesting. I think that the reading and lecture-based structure worked well. The professors were all very knowledgable and looked to help the students succeed.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I like the variety of assignments.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Assignment expectations being made more clear

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: More student participation and engagement would have made this course more stimulating. Sometimes, the lectures went on the whole class without much student participation at all, which, no matter how interesting, I find hard to concentrate on. I wish as well there was less coverage on the law and specific dates and times of discovery and more on the rich and complex histories and relationships of the object to place.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The guest lectures were interesting in making these problems feel real.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I feel that the class would've been way more intellectually stimulating if the professors had gone a little less into the minutiae of the history of the objects and more into general, ethical discussions about the implications of repatriation concerning the artifact at hand. Moreover, I felt like I needed to take a pre-law course to be adequately prepared for this class since the readings were often so lengthy and confusingly worded that they lost all sense of impact on me as a student and were, by no means, intellectually stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Hearing the different points of view of the three professors as well as the guest lecturers, made the class very interesting. It was also stimulating to hear the professors have different areas of expertise.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The topics discussed in this class are very interesting and make you look at issues from various perspectives.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to read a lot and come to class with fully thought-out arguments about the articles.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Would only recommend to someone with an extreme interest in course topics, course has a very Eurocentric focus overall

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Very cool and unique course on looting and archeological objects. Makes you think about the acquisition and placement of objects and cultures around the world in a new way.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: good intersection of a handful of topics -- will offer insight into the all three fields

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Very interesting concept. I have never seen that before of having 3 teachers teach at once. I recommend taking a class like this.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say that this course could certainly be rewarding for someone with a deep interest in archaeology, manuscript studies, ancient cultures, and/or divinity studies. That said, I was sorely disappointed by the fact that it often felt more like a pre-law course or prerequisite history class rather than a supposedly fun, interactive course that I intended to take out of passion--a passion that, because of this course, I caught myself having to repeatedly remind myself why I liked this major and wanted to keep pursuing it in the first place.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You do not need a strong background in art history or religious studies to find the material very interesting.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Developed skills at socratic seminar, learned to read and combine philosophers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I definitely became a more inquisitive person as a result of this class. I began thinking more about systems of governance, their roots, and how we can improve them. I engaged with political theory, some of which I had encountered before and some of which I likely wouldn't have ever gotten to for a lack of interest. This course also oddly rekindled my enjoyment for writing!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the differences between collective governance in ancient democracies and individual freedoms in modern systems. I developed skills in analyzing historical texts and comparing political theories, gaining insight into how these models shape modern debates on civic responsibility and governance.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Ancient vs Modern thinkers in their beliefs on democracy, governance, and human nature.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The required class participation made me stay personally engaged.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We covered political theory from ancient to modern and its implications.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How to read and approach political thought and discussion (I had never done this before in an academic environment).
2. I practice the art of debate and arguing for my viewpoints whilst in the class.
3. I worked on the process of writing papers aided by the scheduled check-ins that our instructor provided.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the differences between the Ancient and Modern times and how civilizations approached democracy. It was interesting to see how different writers had very different opinions at times and the way they defined society made me view the world from different perspectives.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the difference between ancient and modern liberty, I learned about modern influential philosophers and their theories of democracy, I learned how theories of political philosophy drastically shift when they enter the modern era as they face the challenges of modern democracy

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned about the origins of philosophical thoughts on democracy by reading the works of Plato and Aristotle. We then examined how early ideas of democracy helped form American political institutions and the Constitution. Lastly, we learned how to write a philosophy-style paper.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was my first political science class, so I feel like I learned a lot about philosophy, the way political theory informs real life, and how to analyze philosophers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1. how to glean the meaning of dense texts and prioritize information based on relevance to the course when short on time.2. how to compare different political philosophers  by framing their ideologies as dialogues with each other.3. how to think critically and articulate my thoughts concisely through the weekly quizzes.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the ideas of prevailing philosophers such as Aristotle and Plato. I also learned how to make philosophical arguments using evidence.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained an overview of the development of democratic thought from Plato to the moderns, understood some of the modern theory impacting current political thought, and learned how to integrate these ideas over a through a historical narrative.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Evaluating the works of various political philosophers, articulating my opinions about political philosophers, learning about the real-world applications of political philosophy to systems of democracy in our modern day

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about many thinkers (like Habermas, Rawls, and Foucault) that I hadn't read before. One part of the curriculum that really stuck with me was the concept of "ancient liberty" vs "modern liberty" as discussed in Condorcet; that idea guided by thought throughout he semester.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Reading a lot of content-dense material!

Thinking deeply about the world/questioning history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to connect different sources from history to try and get a better understanding of the culture of that time.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned new methods of thinking about history, especially in the context of the Greeks. I improved on my ability to form and develop a historical idea in writing, how to question works as I read them, and to discuss in a setting of peers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about not only Ancient Greece, but how to compare texts across time periods. Doing close readings of different "histories" also taught me how to pick and choose important lines in text to compare to other literature that we read.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to pull seemingly loosely related content from across several primary sources together to create one central thesis or generalization. How to read large volumes of text more efficiently.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I improved my skills in connecting historical pieces to one another in order to make a broader observation. I also learned better in-class discussion/questioning techniques. In terms of new knowledge gained, I learned so much about Greek history; what really stuck with me was elite attitudes towards social issues of ancient Greeks.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think I learned a lot about how to read primary sources in their contexts (understanding the author’s perspective/society), how to synthesize texts to make a broader point about history, and the way people in Ancient Greece articulated and evolved their values.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Thinking about the words between the lines, what is implied, what that means for the world at that time.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I developed insight into the function of Greek governments and societies far beyond the basic understanding most people have.
I learned how to analyze specific word usage in ancient texts in order to understand the feelings of people and the author towards a situation. 
I learned how to ask beyond surface-level questions in regard to literary texts. I learned how to take my original questions and find the deeper meaning behind them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Taught me how to read a lot of content and how to go through all of that information and understand the main ideas. Taught me how to write concise essays comparing and contrasting different work that we've read. Taught me a new perspective on ancient history and what we can take away from it/what it can teach us about the present.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me how to really apply myself to historical texts such as the Iliad or Herodotus and delve into what these texts show about the ancient Greek world. I gained a new appreciation for texts which I had come across before, discussing topics such as how greek concepts of shame and honour differ from our own modern perspectives, etc. Professor Sosin provides fantastic analyses of the sources, making you think outside the box like an academic.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. We learned how to put ourselves in the shoes of people in the past and try to think from their point of view. 
2. We learned how to critically evaluate different pieces of work in relation to each other. 
3. We learned how to derive an idea from observations across multiple texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about Greek history, how to think critically while reading difficult texts, and how to feel confident asking questions in class

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class developed critical thinking, analytical, observational, and creative thinking skills when looking at texts. It also developed historical analysis and thinking, finding relationships between different texts and applying that to think about reasons or how that can fit in a historical context.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to view history through comparative analysis and the evolving ways of thought instead of just through a timeline of events and historical figures.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how crucial empathy is in the study of ancient history, mentally placing yourself in an alien world and judging actions based on that context instead of modern morality. I also learned how to trace historical trends over periods of multiple centuries, understanding how different civilizations evolved and interacted over time. Finally, I improved at the "simple" skill of reading long bits of text, taking ideas from them, and applying these to form wholly new ideas.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Ancient greek culture 
- Ancient Greek History
- Realignment of my personal ethic

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much more about examining primary sources and how to make connections to form broad ideas about Greek history. I also learned how to write concisely and to the point.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned new ways to analyze the historical context and bias of Greek history, as well as the surprising lack of knowledge of the periods that must be extracted from sources that are not always trustworthy. I learned about what was important to the Ancient Greeks to say, do, and preserve, and how these cultural aspects changed, stayed the same, and affected the actions of Greeks in antiquity. And much more!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor keeps students engaged with light-hearted approach to teaching while still staying on topic. Great attitude and vibe.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the structure of the course, with class split between a lecture (that was always engaging, and often entertaining) reinforcing key facts and a discussion period, where questions could be asked. I feel like this format worked great, and should be held onto.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought that the mixture of lecture followed by a short discussion/question period worked very well. I also liked the Daily Questions + a weekly leaf, rather than a traditional five page term paper, as I think it allowed for a broader and deeper engagement with the texts we read.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Created and encouraged many class discussions that increased the spread of ideas, encouraged questioning

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The discussion portion of the class was incredibly helpful in facilitating my understanding and knowledge of Greek history. There was no pressure to have a "good" or "bad" question and Professor Sosin answered every question with the same amount of respect and care. The environment Professor Sosin creates is also incredibly beneficial because there's no judgment. If I ever came to class confused about something I knew I would leave with a much better understanding because of both Professor Sosin's and my peer's helpful responses.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved the lecture style and then into class discussion. I thought that professor Sosin did a great job lecturing on the content that we were assigned for reading. It helped me to really understand what we had been assigned and why it matters in relation to the course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: My favourite parts of the lesson often involved the discussions we have in class. Everyone has their own perspective and thoughts, and so it is interesting to see how peoples ideas differ when looking at the same source. The class environment was good, with Professor Sosin and Anna doing a good job of ensuring that everyone was able to add their input if they wanted to. I personally find it difficult voicing my ideas in front of larger groups, but had no issues with this as the semester progressed, thanks to the environment in the class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really liked when we would have to choose 6 passages that we liked and got to discuss them as a class. I felt like everyone was really excited to discuss these days. I also liked the texts so I dont think I would change the readings.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor facilitated our learning through class discussion every day as well as by assigning short writing assignments each week that helped us to think more critically about the readings/discussions. In future I would keep the mixture of lecture and discussion, and would keep the leaves.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor kept the class engagement high with daily discussion and participation. They also made it a very fun environment by making it very conversational and friendly, introducing fun policies like Lego minifigures for insightful questions/points, and just making history fun and exciting.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Sosin created one of the best learning environments that I have ever experienced. Contributions to the discussions in class were rewarded with little Lego figures, but the agnowledgement of a "interesting question" from professor Sosin was enough to generate thoughtful and intellectual debates and discussion between students. Though I learned a lot from the lecture part of the class, the discussions were invaluable and I looked forward to them.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Sosin's lectures are the most interesting I've encountered at Duke, placing due emphasis on background history but also allowing students to understand texts in their own contexts. He made me proud to be a classics major, possessing a deep command of why the field is such an exciting one to explore. Leaves were a really interesting way to produce new ideas from the texts, reading lengths were fair, and group discussions were a real highlight of the course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Structure and format of the class is great, prof is super knowledgeable and its great to hear him lecture. Lectures are all really great and very rewarding if you engage with the material.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Sosin was absolutely amazing and is definitely one of the best professors I have had. I loved the Q and A format that we used after the small lecture portion.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Really liked Professor Sosin's (and Anna's too!) attitude towards teaching, enthusiasm during class, and pedagogy. Leaves, daily questions, and discussion days were a great way of getting students to meaningfully engage with the material. I also felt that the lack of necessity for leaves to be completely polished pieces of work was an extremely helpful feature that should be included in more classes. Because class engagement was more about the process of forming ideas and processing the course material as opposed to producing results, heavy focus was put on actually enjoying and learning from the material, as opposed to cramming or absorbing it to get a good grade.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think Professor Sosin did a great job getting the class excited about the material and was an excellent lecturer. All of the readings that we discussed were also very interesting to talk about.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The mixture of lecture + discussion was stimulating, as were the readings that were at times difficult but were really interesting. I liked that the readings were primary sources rather than just textbook readings, however I do think that just a little more emphasis on the facts of Greek history/the timeline would have made the class more intellectually stimulating, because while I feel like I did learn a lot in the class I don’t necessarily feel like I left with a clear understanding of the facts of Greek history.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The frequent in-class discussions and questions made the class very intellectually stimulating, as well as the wide range of topics and literature that was read. Also, the fun environment made the class exciting which always helps with involvement/stimulation.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: the discussions were extremely stimulating, and wanting to impress professor Sosin made contributing in class easy and fun!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was made intellectually stimulating in two key ways. First, Sosin was constantly reminding us of the relevance of certain texts and ideas, not just telling but concretely showing why studying the classics is fruitful for human development. Second, the wide variety of application activities (daily questions, leaves, discussions) made it easy to engage with the content on a deeper level, with each type of assignment asking students to consider a different aspect of the material.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: All participation aspects (leaves, daily questions, discussion passages) were heavily stimulating, and not much could be done to make the class more so.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it!!!! It's a lot of reading, and Thucydides isn't the most exciting, but it was my favorite class this year!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This has been one of my favorite history courses at Duke! There are a lot of readings so I wouldn't recommend it if you don't like to read, but otherwise it was great!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! Professor Sosin is very kind, and also teaches the course in a way that is very open to all and all ideas.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I highly recommend taking any class that Professor Sosin teaches.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: While you need to be prepared to do a good bit of reading, and get into the rhythm of submitting daily homework questions, it is beyond worth it to take the course. You don't feel overworked because the material is interesting and fun to learn about. The classtime itself is always engaging and entertaining- you will definitely learn a lot! Overall, its a super fun course, and you'll come out of it feeling like you know a lot more about Greek history than you previously did.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a very fun, very stimulating, very interesting course

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's a lotttt of reading the first few weeks, especially if you're a freshman; the reading gets a lot easier to get through and understand though. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Lastly, I obviously learned about Roman History and just how many enemies they made along the way.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) Appreciative of classical studies, and learning the value of understanding Roman civilization and its beginnings.
2) Being able to identify ancient buildings and artifacts and connecting them with a historical timeline, their importance, their usage, and their development. 
3) Not being afraid of new places. This is my first time traveling abroad. I have never left the US before, much less felt a new culture. I was very afraid at first, but this course has taught me that I am able to be independent in a new cultural setting. My instructors were amazing guides as well, and support was there when needed. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned several new skills in this course. I am now able to connect historical events and figures to archeological and textual evidence. I can notice different styles of cement, frescos, columns, villas, pottery, and statues from the ancient world, dating from the Etruscans through the Hellenistic period and into ancient Rome. I learned how to recognize mythological themes in archeological sights. I also learned how to compare various burial methods, banqueting styles, and gender roles as they changed throughout Roman history. I know to challenge textual accounts of events, for they might be exaggerated or biased.  
Further, this course helped me adapt to living in a new city! I learned how to compile the little Italian I know to make my way around the neighborhoods. I learned Italian dining and social customs and how to order food in restaurants. Overall, I feel that I am able to immerse myself in the new culture and experience it to its fullest potential.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned an incredible about Roman history, literature and archaeology. I am able to identify different styles of frescos and different columns that were constructed. I am much more familiar with Roman mythology and literature. I also became very familiar with Rome, in terms of navigating the country as well as the culture and cuisine.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about why the Ancient Romans had the spectacles they had such as the gladiator fights, beast hunts, and chariot races. Even though gladiator fights are probably the most well-known widely, especially as brutally violent, almost sadistic spectacles, they had a greater purpose in Roman society at the time. I also learned that there was a time when the Romans did not build permanent spectacle buildings but rather built temporary ones but with good reason. I have developed a better understanding of this ancient civilization in particular and this has also allowed me to be more open-minded when it comes to thinking out other cultures or civilizations doing things that may seem odd to us but make a lot of sense when you see it from their perspective.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I did not come to Duke to study ancient Anatolia.  But I did come to Duke to take classes that promoted intellectually rigorous environments.  Kate Morgan's class on Iron Age Phrygia and Lydia promoted the environment that I had been looking for.  While Kate Morgan is indisputably one of the rising stars in the study of ancient Anatolia and near East and has accumulated more hours in the trenches of Gordion than I have spent in the Perkins Library, she does not try to teach a version of "Archaeological Methods" or "Phrygian Burnished Ware Typologies."  She assigns readings and directs class discussion with an eye to how non archaeologists can wrangle not just with the material evidence from such a fascinating part of the world (e.g. she assigns ancient testimonia on Gordion and Sardis; I got my Homer and Herodotus fix), but how they can wrangle with larger questions of reconstructing the past.  Kate Morgan is as great a practitioner of Altertumswissenschaft as they come, juxtaposing context against text; destruction layer with destruction layer; history with historiography.  Her expectations for discussion and course participation are high; she is disappointed when they are not met (although she is much too considerate to say anything about it).  But in the end, she cultivates an enriching class atmosphere that makes me grateful that I came to Duke.
