question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: My biggest take-away from this course was learning how to write for different audiences. We had to write pieces for general audiences including program notes for a play and an article for a publication like "Eidolon." Since I'm usually tasked with writing for an academic audience, I found this very challenging and valuable. I was also pushed to incorporate knowledge and methodologies from classics into my own field. Finally, I tried and sometimes successfully spoke to a group of people about my area of interest in non-jargony ways.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Critical reception theory (and introductions to several other forms of theory)
How to deconstruct myths like the 'Greek miracle' or the descent of modern white culture from ancient Greece, and how these myths have pervaded Classics and our broader culture
Writing for a general audience
Pitching a project

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained insight into reception studies, a field which I previously didn't know much about. I also read a lot of interesting and important theory, which we put to practice applying. The focus on areas other than literature was engaging, insightful, and a welcome change.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the Orpheus myth, I also learned how to engage in class discussion in a more collaborative way than I had experienced previously, and learned how to apply reception theory to Classical history and question more about what we consider 'Classical.'

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a new theoretical approach that I could use in my own research, and the three key points that changed my perspective while a researcher in the humanities field were: 1- look at the classic presence in any period considering the historical constructions of those notions and symbols; 2- think about questions of value and how they are a historical construction that may imply a eurocentric/western perspective; 3- classical reception can be used for good and bad: look at the implications and be critical of any classical reinterpretation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned new ways of approaching classical reception by evaluating how certain biases form our perceptions of the "classical past." I also learned the many theories that encompass classical reception studies, as well as how to apply these theories in a concrete and critical way.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Gained familiarity with important methods of critical classical reception 
2. Examined a variety of reception examples from recent culture 
3. Examined the hegemonic structures that underly some of our society’s understanding of the classics

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about several new forms of critical theory and how to apply them to various "texts" (e.g. writing, visual art, film), learned about the history of Classical Reception over time and methods for considering why the context of a certain time and place resulted in specific forms of reception, and learned how to write analytically about forms of media other than text, which is what I am used to working with.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the field of critical classical reception studies (what a critical approach means, the conservative and problematic aspects of the discipline of classics, various disciplinary interventions), about reception as a whole (how our relationship to the past is not necessarily linear but how it can be productive to think of past and present in dialogue, as actively created), and how to think more critically about disciplines and their epistemologies - not just classics (for example, classics is built on epistemologies that are exclusive, which means an inclusive approach isn't just 'raising up unheard voices' but actually rethinking the structure of how we learn the discipline and how it is inherently colonial, discriminatory).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The course provided a useful introduction to a field that I was just partially familiar with. It was particularly useful to have the chance to read a very diverse selection of scholarship and reflect on a lot of different cases at first alone and then together with the class. Also, I think the assignments were an important chance to work on communication and popularization of Classics outside academia.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was extremely helpful in providing me with the tools to think critically about how the ancient world has been perceived and reimagined throughout time. The topic of reception is one that I have always been interested in, but I have never had the framework to really understand it in this way. Our readings and case studies showed us how we could apply a critical lens to the interpretation of the past. Most importantly, we kept returning to the question of "so what?" Why does this matter and what's at stake with these topics? Learning how to dissect an example of classical reception and understand it more critically was a skill I will be practicing in my own work a lot going forward. If I had to identify three specific things that I learned, I would say that I learned how to "read" reception (how to understand what I was encountering and how to unpack it), I learned to ask why something matters, and I learned how to apply these concepts to my own work.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really valued our pair and share times. There was a great mix of group discussion, one on one discussion, and journaling. It helped keep me engaged in a 2 1/2 hour seminar.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the cultural critique show-and-tells would be a great thing to keep for future iterations of the course: they encourage us to bring the ways of thinking we learn in the course to things we encounter outside the course, and it's always great to learn what other students are interested in. Practicing writing for a general audience was also a good skill to start picking up.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I'm not great in class discussion, nor in small groups--I understand that it's very important to be collaborative, so I do love it in that regard and wouldn't suggest changing it. But the parts that facilitated my learning were more in line with the solitary work--the frequent journaling, reading, and project work. I also very much enjoyed the cultural critique show and tells!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I'll remember how generous and kind the professor was with speaking to students, there was a lot of respect in this classroom that was largely fostered by the professor.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course was really well organized, with a manageable number of readings and a great variety of assignments that allowed me to experiment with new learning methods. The flexibility regarding the final project and the opportunity to develop critical thinking through small assignments were really efficient in terms of didactics. Besides that, the sources of learning were also really diverse, from academic papers, books, films, musicals, and visits to museums and theaters, and that was amazing; I could really engage with the topics discussed in more fun ways than only reading difficult texts.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The environment of the class was very open and inviting. At the beginning of the course, Erika emphasized that all opinions and perspectives are welcome, which made our class conversations very interesting and instructive. I feel like I have learned how to question my own perspectives by listening to the many different viewpoints of others.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
1. Cultural critique show-and-tells (very interesting and added variety)
2. Varied media in examples of reception (lit, film, music etc.) 
3. Discussion-based class format (suited subject matter)

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Weiberg is very good at facilitating in-class discussion between students and guiding these conversations when necessary. She clearly knows the material very well and is able to guide students towards getting the most knowledge out of it that they can. She also takes student input and feedback into account when creating and adjusting assignments. During each class meeting, there was always a schedule laying out what topics and texts we would be discussing that day, which was very helpful in organizing class sessions. Students had to complete one individual presentation on a topic of their choice, called a "Cultural Critique Show and Tell," which was extremely helpful in learning to apply the material covered in class. Dr. Weiberg was also willing to meet with students to discuss assignments and potential research topics, and always provided valuable input in the form of ideas and scholarly resources during these meetings.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the structure of discussion, which pushed us to speak up in the seminar and bring up the topics that we would like to discuss. I also think the structure of self-grading and evaluating was very helpful and generous! Prof. Weiberg was great at still giving feedback promptly on our presentations, abstracts, and things, which was super helpful and productive without the pressure of a grade. She was also very receptive to meeting outside of class for office hours and lovely to work with.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The frequent discussions, either in groups or with the class, were important to be able to learn about different perspectives on the same topics. The instructor used active listening in many situations, helping people transmit their opinions to the rest of the class in a clear way even when the topics o were particularly complex and nuanced.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that when Erika let us have a more free-flowing discussion (rather than having us raise our hands), that conversations moved more naturally and people felt less concerned with having a right or wrong answer. I think if it was stated more explicitly to not raise hands but just jump into a conversation, then things might be easier for students. Also, I liked working in small groups (especially when we were told to mix it up from our neighbors), and collaborative projects like the Nasher presentation and the Eurydice program notes were definitely exercises that I enjoyed!I always really appreciated that slides are posted each week because it lets me follow along and focus better. Having resources available to students is very helpful and it gives us a sense of what to expect, as well as access to the material without needing to ask the professor for it.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I was constantly negotiating how to use my knowledge and training for people who have no expertise in my area. That is such an important skill in both writing and teaching. I think I'll take that forward with me.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Discussion, engagement with all sorts of modern media and non-academic texts as well as academic texts, inclusion of students from multiple disciplines

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: LOTS of engagement with theories and discussion of difficult and nuanced topics.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I wish there was greater diversity in topics. After weeks of Orpheus and Eurydice, I would get so excited to see new topics come up on our syllabus and really be engaged in class discussion, only for the discussion to go right back to Orpheus. I genuinely have nothing more to contribute on that topic that hasn't already been repeatedly said and it felt a bit isolating. I still looked forward to this class because of how respectful and excellent of an instructor Professor Weiberg is, but the material of the course itself could be more varied.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The variety of knowledge sources and how the discussions were conducted: splitting the class into small groups to organize the thoughts with peers and then bringing them to the broader class discussion.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think the material and readings for this class were interesting and relevant and the discussions in class were engaging.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The material that this course covered was interesting in and of itself, but classroom discussions were always facilitated in a very helpful and engaging way, which contributed to the level of intellectual stimulation. Additionally, although the class had a strong unifying theme, a different theory, topic, or lens was focused on in each session, which always kept things interesting. It was also engaging to have students from multiple disciplines with various interests in the class, since everyone brought a different perspective to the course material.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
The topic in itself was very engaging, for people of all backgrounds, because the classics is so embedded in our "Western" culture- and that is something we looked critically at. I also enjoyed the range of materials we looked at - myth, literature, secondary theory, art, film, popular culture. 
It is a great way to be self-reflexive and self-conscious about our disciplines - the goal is not just to gain information or knowledge but to look in complex, considerate, and nuanced ways about how knowledge is built, passed down, and naturalized.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The topic itself was very stimulating, but I would say the most stimulating parts were the questions we were continuously asked to think about and the material we were thinking about, reworking, and producing for our assignments. It was great to try to put in practice what we were learning.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The readings were probably my favorite part of this class. Every reading was super interesting and insightful, and I couldn't get enough. I kept checking out more books from the library after every class because I wanted to read more. Class discussions were also very stimulating, and it was helpful to hear peoples' perspectives on readings and examples (especially since there was a good mix of academic backgrounds/areas of interest).

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take it because even if classics isn't your thing, you gain a lot of valuable skills that can go to any field.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Get ready for some very stimulating and thought provoking readings and discussions!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Don't be afraid to speak your mind. Also be really familiar with the Orpheus and Eurydice myth.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a very good course for anyone interested in learning about classical reception, and you do not need to have a previous background to learn about it with this course. It will give everything you need to learn, from introductory debates to more field-specific approaches.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Erika is a wonderful instructor who has clearly put a lot of time and effort into developing a course that actively engages with many aspects of classical reception studies, from theory to visual media. I especially liked how we were given the opportunity to apply what we learned to an actual production of Sarah Ruhl's Eurydice at Duke, making what we learned feel much more relevant and pertinent  to something beyond the classroom.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would encourage another student to take this course because it has been engaging in itself and because the things discussed can be useful in the future with respect to a wide variety of topics and circumstances. I also think this course can help people think more ethically as scholars, even if they don’t directly use these methods or ideas in their own work.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The course requires a non-insignificant time commitment, but the knowledge that the student gains through it will broaden their intellectual horizons in manifold directions and make them a better scholar of Classical Studies, a better scholar of reception studies, and a better scholar in general. The course strengthens critical thinking skills, writing and presentation skills, and the ability to apply theory. Additionally, the subject matter is deeply interesting and readings cover a wide array of topics and forms, so there will be something that speaks to everyone.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is wonderful for anyone with an interest in classics, no matter the experience level or disciplinary background. It introduces students to a host of myths built up about "Western civilization" and culture that should be examined critically and carefully through a range of approaches (feminism, disability studies, trauma theory, and more). It has deep relevance for the present and for academia in general, as you learn how to look for exclusionary, prejudiced structures built into scholarly disciplines. It is also enjoyable to look into a range of media and materials - from myth, to film, to popular culture, to ancient literature.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
This course is definitely worth everyone's time, whether they are or not students in the Classics field. It can help shed light on so many aspects of contemporary issues.
Also, Professor Weiberg is an instructor who clearly puts a lot of thought into ensuring not only that their students are learning and engaging with the materials but also that they are encouraged to do so confidently and in the best class environment possible.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this class!!! If you are someone who studies the ancient world, the concepts we covered are essential to understand if you want to be a responsible scholar. Honestly, a reception course should probably be required for students of classics. Even if you don't study the ancient world, you will start to see history and the world in a new way. Classical reception is all around us, and it's really important to recognize how it is being used and abused.Also, Erika is an amazing professor!!!!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about how approach the research process and how to engage with primary sources not just as text but as whole historical objects to be explored. This course allowed me to then apply these research methods to a primary source through the manuscript project.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Broader knowledge of the field of material studies in general and Christian manuscript cultures in particular. Methods of analyzing a manuscript, from production to provenance. Insights into the scholarly methodologies at play in the field, and an idea of what kind of scholarship is being done today. Thinking more critically about how to analyze a piece of scholarship concerning manuscript cultures.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One of the main themes of this class was exploring the ethics behind manuscript collections and acquisitions. In addition, we gained competency in accessing rare manuscripts from the Rubenstein collection and how to prepare for a visit effectively. Finally, I learned to think critically of manuscripts are material objects in their own right with stories to tell, rather than as mere repositories of disembodied text.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: A much more comprehensive understanding of manuscript studies, and all that entails, which I previously had no interaction with

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
How to use collections
How to read miniscule
How to begin to study a manuscript!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to conduct provenance research, how to conduct provenience research, and how to trace textual transmission.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course served as an introduction to the field of manuscript studies and to Duke's Rubenstein collection. I felt that I learned about the field's evolution as well as its current state. Through this course, I have begun to think about historical texts as material objects as well as texts. The opportunity to consider our chosen manuscripts from the angles of content, provenience and provenance helped develop this skill.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a working knowledge of the basics of manuscript studies, an orientation to the use of manuscripts for my further research on various ancient texts, and the ethical stakes of modern provenance research.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really liked the discussion leaders and how they and Dr. Knust would provide handouts for each week. It really helped me to focus during class and I think helped the class discussion stay on track while also allowing for tangents when they organically occurred from the discussion. I also think being assigned a manuscript for the whole semester is a brilliant idea and I really enjoyed all aspects of that project.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I found the student-led seminars very helpful both from the perspective of running them and receiving them. I also found the work of analyzing a manuscript in the Rubenstein collection deeply engaging and very exciting--an excellent opportunity to put into practice the theory being discussed in class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the opportunities to practice seminar leadership and felt that the requirement to do it twice allowed for growth throughout the semester.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: As someone new to the field, I was consistently impressed with Dr. Knust's ability to not fall into overly technical language and keep the content engaging and relevant. Without compromising depth and technical skill development, we were able to have bigger-picture conversations about meaning, method, and even justice.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Jenny and Nick were both very approachable in and out of class for questions, whether specific or broad. I particularly enjoyed sitting with them and trying to drill down into the specifics of my manuscript and its history. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class was very informative and engaging for me. I learned a lot about how museums work and what ethical concerns are involved. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I developed knowledge about archaeological practices, the role of museums when hosting archaeological finds/discoveries, and how interconnected archaeology is with other aspects of the world, like politics, education, and media.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained helpful insight into the often unethical methods in which museums acquire artifacts, how museums create a narrative about the artifacts they display (which may be informed by a colonial background), and how to utilize debunking techniques to convince others to use reason-- in the context of pseudoarchaeology and beyond.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Judson always came to class with a plan and very through slides to help facilitate our conversations and teach us about each subject we learned. Every topic flowed well and helped build a bigger picture. I loved our conversations and the times where we had to take a topic we just learned and dive into what interested us the most (in our annotated bibliographies, research paper, and creative writing project).

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Overall I would say the learning environment the instructor facilitated for this class was very fitting for the material. I loved all the group projects especially the one where students design their own monument! In general there isn't much I would change about this course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I deeply enjoyed the lecture + seminar format, and found Professor Watkins to be a great facilitator of in-class debates. The reading notes & discussion guides provided were deeply helpful in parsing historical texts/beliefs. Would have appreciated a slight tilt towards the instructional lecture formats (to ensure discussions were kept high-quality and nuanced) instead of the seminar discussions, but still found it productive nevertheless.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The readings and reading responses before each class ensured that I developed a comprehensive understanding of the material before each discussion, Then, the discussion-based format each class was a great way to learn and understand a wide variety of viewpoints from every student. I found myself thinking in new way and questioning my own beliefs every class which was refreshing. The required papers were also a great way to engage with the philosophers we read while integrating philosophy with the history we'd learn about in the readings. I appreciated the freedom for each paper, with 3 prompts we could choose from.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

response_text: I knew a bit about looting and provenance as I worked at the nasher reorganizing their provenance files however I didn’t know the legal side of things and this class really introduced me to that.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a significant amount of knowledge regarding how to approach provenance research, balance the complexities of repatriation cases, and navigate the challenging duality of legality and ethics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about how art and artifacts have been used as symbols of power and have been stolen throughout history. I also learned about the legal side of culteral protection which I did not know much about.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to look at the possession of cultural artifacts critically, how to examine and research the provenance of objects and artifacts, and how the repatriation of cultural artifacts works.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Loved the open dialogue and that the profs willingly shared their opinions!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Readings correlated to class discussion, detailed feedback given on assignments

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved the variety of readings and in-depth case studies we did. I particularly liked the field trip as we got to get a hands-on experience with what we had been learning and then got to research an object connected to the place we visited. I would continue to have a variety of topics in the lectures, activities, and field trips.

- motifs of individual looted objects that tracked along the themes we studied

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Having 3 different professors with 3 different areas of expertise was really helpful. We got such a developed view of the issues that way.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors worked incredibly hard to facilitate our learning by routinely interjecting lectures to ask the students for active feedback. As such, we were constantly encouraged to participate and reflect on the readings that we did before classes. The occasional in-person outside speaker series were an aspect of the class that I believe should be kept for future years since it was such a delight to have such groundbreaking professionals as Patty Gerstenblith and Morag Kersel speak to our class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the form of doing background readings before lecture was useful; the research assignments also fit the themes of the course well.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course was very interesting. I think that the reading and lecture-based structure worked well. The professors were all very knowledgable and looked to help the students succeed.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I like the variety of assignments.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Assignment expectations being made more clear

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: More student participation and engagement would have made this course more stimulating. Sometimes, the lectures went on the whole class without much student participation at all, which, no matter how interesting, I find hard to concentrate on. I wish as well there was less coverage on the law and specific dates and times of discovery and more on the rich and complex histories and relationships of the object to place.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The guest lectures were interesting in making these problems feel real.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I feel that the class would've been way more intellectually stimulating if the professors had gone a little less into the minutiae of the history of the objects and more into general, ethical discussions about the implications of repatriation concerning the artifact at hand. Moreover, I felt like I needed to take a pre-law course to be adequately prepared for this class since the readings were often so lengthy and confusingly worded that they lost all sense of impact on me as a student and were, by no means, intellectually stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Hearing the different points of view of the three professors as well as the guest lecturers, made the class very interesting. It was also stimulating to hear the professors have different areas of expertise.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The topics discussed in this class are very interesting and make you look at issues from various perspectives.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to read a lot and come to class with fully thought-out arguments about the articles.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Would only recommend to someone with an extreme interest in course topics, course has a very Eurocentric focus overall

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Very cool and unique course on looting and archeological objects. Makes you think about the acquisition and placement of objects and cultures around the world in a new way.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: good intersection of a handful of topics -- will offer insight into the all three fields

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Very interesting concept. I have never seen that before of having 3 teachers teach at once. I recommend taking a class like this.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say that this course could certainly be rewarding for someone with a deep interest in archaeology, manuscript studies, ancient cultures, and/or divinity studies. That said, I was sorely disappointed by the fact that it often felt more like a pre-law course or prerequisite history class rather than a supposedly fun, interactive course that I intended to take out of passion--a passion that, because of this course, I caught myself having to repeatedly remind myself why I liked this major and wanted to keep pursuing it in the first place.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You do not need a strong background in art history or religious studies to find the material very interesting.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would recommend this course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Knowledge of art markets, value systems, and the shady side of art and archaeology. I learned to think more critically in instances of nuance where an argument for one side or another is difficult.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Historical questioning, ethical questioning, research

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think about loot as an all-encompassing reality (cultural, historical, and archeological settings as well as aspects of law, colonialism, oppression, war, and money). I also learned how to interpret the provenance and provenience of objects to think critically and deeply about whether it is loot. I also learned how to read complex articles, books, and journals that go into the details of an object's history and present circumstances as well as find provenance of an object who does not have much known provenance.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- moral considerations surrounding the ownership of cultural heritage
- evaluation of contested institutions such as museums, archives, and libraries
- (il)legal appropriation of sacred objects

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about how approach the research process and how to engage with primary sources not just as text but as whole historical objects to be explored. This course allowed me to then apply these research methods to a primary source through the manuscript project.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Broader knowledge of the field of material studies in general and Christian manuscript cultures in particular. Methods of analyzing a manuscript, from production to provenance. Insights into the scholarly methodologies at play in the field, and an idea of what kind of scholarship is being done today. Thinking more critically about how to analyze a piece of scholarship concerning manuscript cultures.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One of the main themes of this class was exploring the ethics behind manuscript collections and acquisitions. In addition, we gained competency in accessing rare manuscripts from the Rubenstein collection and how to prepare for a visit effectively. Finally, I learned to think critically of manuscripts are material objects in their own right with stories to tell, rather than as mere repositories of disembodied text.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: A much more comprehensive understanding of manuscript studies, and all that entails, which I previously had no interaction with

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
How to use collections
How to read miniscule
How to begin to study a manuscript!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to conduct provenance research, how to conduct provenience research, and how to trace textual transmission.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course served as an introduction to the field of manuscript studies and to Duke's Rubenstein collection. I felt that I learned about the field's evolution as well as its current state. Through this course, I have begun to think about historical texts as material objects as well as texts. The opportunity to consider our chosen manuscripts from the angles of content, provenience and provenance helped develop this skill.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a working knowledge of the basics of manuscript studies, an orientation to the use of manuscripts for my further research on various ancient texts, and the ethical stakes of modern provenance research.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really liked the discussion leaders and how they and Dr. Knust would provide handouts for each week. It really helped me to focus during class and I think helped the class discussion stay on track while also allowing for tangents when they organically occurred from the discussion. I also think being assigned a manuscript for the whole semester is a brilliant idea and I really enjoyed all aspects of that project.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I found the student-led seminars very helpful both from the perspective of running them and receiving them. I also found the work of analyzing a manuscript in the Rubenstein collection deeply engaging and very exciting--an excellent opportunity to put into practice the theory being discussed in class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the opportunities to practice seminar leadership and felt that the requirement to do it twice allowed for growth throughout the semester.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Having students present topics as the year went by helped a lot to give different perspectives

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: All of it!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved getting hands-on experience with textual material. It was great to be able to work through course materials with a tangible example!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: As someone new to the field, I was consistently impressed with Dr. Knust's ability to not fall into overly technical language and keep the content engaging and relevant. Without compromising depth and technical skill development, we were able to have bigger-picture conversations about meaning, method, and even justice.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Jenny and Nick were both very approachable in and out of class for questions, whether specific or broad. I particularly enjoyed sitting with them and trying to drill down into the specifics of my manuscript and its history. They were both humble, acknowledging the difficulty in the field, but helpful guides as well.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This course was very stimulating because even though the focus is on ancient/late ancient religious texts, the readings and discussions brought in a bunch of different angles. So while a lot of the readings focuses on papyri for example, I was still able to take away a lesson in research methods or approaches for my own scholarship.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The quality of work from my peers matched the high expectations of the instructors.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think it was exciting to see all the different backgrounds represented here and the vast array of different manuscripts we worked with.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The resdings, discussion, and our individual projects were great

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: No specific ideas and/or recommendations

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The level of thought my classmates put into the readings.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The variety of images, reading assignments, discussion topics, and students in different disciplines made the class stimulating.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a great introduction to the world of book history and archival work. Even if they don't have much history in the ancient/medieval world, the research skills learned can be adapted into any area of historical study.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Absolutely take it. It will be most helpful to you if you have interest in the field, but regardless of whether you intend to make a career out of manuscript studies, the pedagogy from Drs. Knust and Wagner is excellent formation for scholars.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class was a wonderful introduction to manuscript work in the field of Early Christianity. I'd recommend it for anyone pursuing Doctoral work in the field.

response_text: It is challenging and stimulating!
